title: 104_s817
content:
The "United States Buffalo Nickel Act of 1995" mandates the minting of 5-cent coins with specific specifications for a 3-year period. The coins will weigh 5 grams, have a diameter of 0.835 inches, and contain an alloy of 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will only obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stockpiling Act. The design of the coins will be specified. The design of the coins minted under this Act will be a reproduction of the original 5-cent coin designed by James Earle Fraser from 1913 to 1938, featuring a Native American profile and a buffalo. Each coin will include the coin's value, year, and inscriptions of "United States of America", "Liberty", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs. The design of the coins minted under this Act will be a reproduction of the original 5-cent coin designed by James Earle Fraser from 1913 to 1938, featuring a Native American profile and a buffalo. The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs, the Committee on Indian Affairs, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Only 1 facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular combination of denomination and quality of the coins minted under this Act. The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act beginning January 1, 1998. No coins may be minted under this Act after December 31, 2000. 

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

Coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales will include a $1.00 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. The Park Maintenance and Upkeep Fund is established by the National Park Foundation for maintenance, repair, and upkeep of National Park System facilities. Surcharges from coin sales are deposited into the Fund, with no funds used for new facility construction. The Foundation establishes the Park Maintenance and Upkeep Fund for National Park System facilities. Surcharges from coin sales are deposited into the Fund, not considered Treasury revenues. The Foundation allocates funds to meet National Park Service priority needs. The Comptroller General can audit Fund expenditures. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Coins can only be issued if payment is received, security is provided, or a guarantee of payment from a depository institution is in place.
